Graphical abstract Thorough theoretical analysis of structural and electronic effects supported by model experiments can be used for the rational design of new electrocatalytic materials. Recent advances in the understanding of structural and electronic effects in heterogeneous electrocatalysis are summarized. Typical examples are given illustrating how the knowledge obtained from a detailed theoretical analysis of structural and electronic effects supported by model experiments can be used for the rational design of new electrocatalytic materials. Recent successes and future challenges in designing active, stable, and selective electrocatalysts are discussed. Keywords Electrocatalysis Surface science Electronic effects Structural effects 1 Introduction Electrocatalysis is the field of catalysis that deals with the catalysis of redox reactions. Redox reactions not only play a key role in a multitude of devices, in particular electrochemical power sources such as fuel cells, batteries, and electrolyzers, but also in many naturally occurring processes, especially those related to energy conversion in living systems. There is growing awareness that the way that mankind will secure future availability of sustainable energy will depend heavily on electrochemistry, as it allows the storage and consumption of electrons in chemical bonds at ambient conditions. It is the task of electrocatalysis to make this process as efficient, reversible, robust, and cost-effective as possible. The aim of this Anniversary Article for the Journal of Catalysis is to pull together some recent advances in the understanding of structural and electronic effects in heterogeneous electrocatalysis, i.e., the area of electrocatalysis which makes use of solid metal or oxide electrodes as electrocatalysts. We note that electrocatalysis is not limited to heterogeneous catalysts: molecular catalysts, either in solution or immobilized on a conductive but otherwise inert support, may also catalyze redox reactions. Redox proteins are Nature’s electrocatalysts and essentially function as galvanic cells, very much like in a discharging battery. Therefore, the field of electrocatalysis bridges many areas of catalysis. Here, we show how the study of a few selected electrocatalytic reactions on well-defined, often single-crystalline, electrode surfaces has lead to a detailed insight into the atomic-level aspects that impact on electrocatalytic performance. Often, these studies have been supported by first-principles density functional theory calculations. The insight thus obtained leads to useful design rules in the development of real-world high surface-area nanoparticulate catalysts. The paper consists of three main sections. In Section 2, we provide a brief overview on electronic and structural effects in the field of electrocatalysis. In Section 3, we discuss how the atomic arrangement of the atoms at the electrode surface influences its catalytic activity, and we propose that this may categorized into three main classes of structure sensitivity. Each of these classes is then catalyzed by differently shaped nanoparticles, as follows from the insight obtained from single-crystal studies. In Section 4, we demonstrate how the catalyst composition influences the electronic properties of the topmost atomic layer of the surface and how this can be used to design efficient electrocatalysts. In a final section, we will summarize our main conclusions and sketch the possible perspectives for future research work. 2 Structural vs. electronic effects in electrocatalysis Industrial electrocatalysts are typically produced either as nanoparticles or (porous) extended layers to increase the overall useful surface [1]. If a nanoparticulate material is used, the nanoparticles are immobilized on a conducting support developed to work under conditions of catalyzed electrochemical reactions [2]. It should be noted that ready-to-use electrocatalytic materials are complex systems where the resultant performance, i.e., activity, selectivity and stability, depends on many factors. Even a single-supported nanoparticle in contact with an electrolyte represents a multiparametric system [3]: different facets, surface defects, interactions with the support material, surface and bulk composition, size effects, specific properties of the electrochemical interface, electrolyte composition, and other parameters [4] control its catalytic properties (Fig. 1 ). Therefore, in order to gain deeper understanding of these systems and to be able to develop a new generation of electrocatalysts, it is essential to simplify the system and use model objects, where all these aspects are investigated separately in detail [5–11]. Apart from the complexity of electrocatalytic systems, one can broadly distinguish at least two major effects that influence the whole variety of parameters. Basically, the resultant catalytic performance of active sites at the surface essentially depends on two intrinsically interconnected effects: (i) structural effects and (ii) electronic effects. The former are important to elucidate and understand the contribution of different facets, steps, kinks, and atoms with lower coordination number to the overall electrocatalytic activity. For a given electrocatalytic material, it is critical to find the surface sites, which are responsible for the observed catalytic activity (or selectivity) and use this knowledge to design new catalysts or optimized existing catalysts. The electronic effects determine the electronic status of active sites or facets. Those effects are taken into the analysis when the active sites are identified, and their electronic properties should further be adjusted, e.g., by changing the (local) chemical composition. The design of new efficient electrocatalysts assumes that structural and electronic effects are analyzed equally. However, in practice, there could be different situations. If the choice of the materials is very limited, pure structural effects play the dominant role, as only they provide the necessary degree of freedom to optimize the catalyst performance. It is then essential to create an abundance of the most active sites, for instance, specific facets or atoms with a lower coordination number. Alternatively, if the choice of material is wider and the most active sites are known, further optimization of their electronic structure (e.g., by changing the composition) becomes critical. Ideally, structural and electronic effects have to be taken into account simultaneously: then, both composition and surface structure are optimized in parallel. In practice, rational development of efficient electrocatalysts requires application of many different techniques, methods, and model objects. On the one hand, techniques of electrochemistry alone cannot provide all the necessary information about the surface and the electrochemical interface [12,13]. The whole arsenal of ultra-high vacuum surface science techniques [14] and in situ spectro-electrochemical approaches [12,15–19] is also required to characterize and tailor [20,21] the surface. Additionally, modern quantum chemical methods can give valuable insight when the necessary information is not directly available from the experiments [22]. On the other hand, model objects help in better understanding of electrocatalyst performance, including low- and high-index single-crystal surfaces [6,23], well-defined (for instance, size-selected or shape-controlled) nanoparticles, thin films (often with a monolayer thickness), and some other specific objects to investigate different aspects influencing the catalytic performance separately. In the following sections, we show how the knowledge obtained from a thorough theoretical analysis of structural and electronic effects supported by model experiments can be used for the rational design of new electrocatalytic materials. 3 Structural effects in electrocatalysis 3.1 Electrocatalysis on single-crystal surfaces The idea that the activity of a heterogeneous catalyst depends on the structure of its surface dates back to Taylor’s original concept of the “active site” [24]. The surface-science approach to identifying the active site on a surface is to study the reaction under consideration on a number of single-crystal surfaces. Ideally, these surfaces sample a relevant part of the stereographic triangle, as illustrated for fcc metals in Fig. 2 . Such studies should give insight into which arrangement of surface atoms leads to the highest activity and should thereby identify the active site(s) for a reaction. Many relevant electrocatalytic reactions have been studied using this surface science approach, having generated a wealth of information of the activity of a large variety of electrocatalytic reactions on single-crystal surfaces of different metals. A recent comparison of these single-crystal studies suggested that many electrocatalytic reactions fall within one of three categories of structure sensitivity [11]: (1) Electrocatalytic reactions that take place preferentially on step and defect sites within (111) terraces. Typically, the key step in these reactions involves the breaking or making of an O–H or C–H bond, such as the oxidation of methanol or the oxidation of carbon monoxide (which depends on the activation of water). (2) Electrocatalytic reactions that take place preferentially on (100) terrace sites. For these reactions, steps and defects in the (100) terraces lead to a decrease in catalytic activity. These reactions invariably involve the breaking or making of a C–O, C–C, N–O, N–N, or O–O bond. (3) Electrocatalytic reactions that do not appear to have a clear preference for a particular site or crystal surface. Typically, the structure sensitivity of these reactions is very sensitive to the presence of other ingredients of the electrochemical interface, such as anions, especially if the specific adsorption of these anions is structure sensitive. These reactions often involve intermediates that are only relatively weakly adsorbed on metal surfaces. A good and classic example of the first category is the electrocatalytic oxidation of carbon monoxide [26]. The key step in the oxidation of (chemisorbed) carbon monoxide is the formation of an adsorbed hydroxyl on a free site on the surface: (1) H 2 O + ∗ ⇆ OH ads + H + + e - This reaction takes place preferentially at step and defect sites owing to the more favorable binding of OH on those sites. The OHads reacts with COads in a Langmuir–Hinshelwood reaction to yield CO2: (2) CO ads + OH ads → CO 2 + 2 ∗ + H + + e - The potential-determining step, i.e., the thermodynamically least favorable step in this mechanism, is the formation of the surface-bonded hydroxyl reaction (1). Since OH prefers to bind to step sites, the reaction is thermodynamically most favorable at step sites. The preferred binding of adsorbates such as OH and CO to low-coordination surface atoms is related to the higher energy of the center of the d band at such sites [27]. Therefore, the step site acts as the active site for the reaction. Fig. 3 illustrates the chronoamperometric transients of the oxidation of a pre-adsorbed saturated monolayer of CO on three different stepped electrodes (but at the same potential) in sulfuric acid, with varying step density [28]. In the experiment, CO is adsorbed at a low potential at which the CO adlayer is stable. CO is then removed from the electrolyte solution, and the potential is stepped to a potential at which the CO adlayer is oxidized following the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism given by reactions (1) and (2). Qualitatively, the comparison of the transients clearly shows that increasing the step density leads to a faster oxidation of the chemisorbed CO adlayer. Quantitatively, the peaked shape of the current transient is a direct consequence of the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism. An expression for the current density transient j(t) can be derived from a mathematical modeling of reactions (1) and (2) [29]: (3) j ( t ) = 2 F Γ m kC exp ( - kt ) [ 1 + C exp ( - kt ) ] 2 where C =ln[θin /(1− θin )] with θin the coverage of CO at t =0, F is Faraday’s constant, Γm is the number of adsorption sites per cm−2, and k is the effective rate constant of reaction (2), including the (quasi-equilibrium) coverage of OHads at the electrode potential under consideration. A fit of Eq. (3) to the transients in Fig. 4 shows that this rate constant is proportional to the step density [28]. Therefore, it was concluded that the OH adsorbs preferentially at the steps, and CO oxidizes only there, and not at the (111) terraces. A very similar conclusion was reached for the oxidation of chemisorbed CO on rhodium single crystals in acidic media [30–32] and on platinum single crystals in alkaline media [33,34], though the details of the electrochemical response was rather different, suggesting slow CO diffusion on the terraces by strongly adsorbed anions [32] or by the temporary blocking of the active sites after CO oxidation, perhaps by carbonate, the oxidation product [34]. The oxidation of methanol and ethanol was also found to be structure sensitive and to be catalyzed by the presence of steps in the surface, which was ascribed to the structure sensitivity of the initial dehydrogenation step of the alcohol [35,36]. Such O–H or C–H bond breaking reactions have been predicted by quantum-chemical considerations to take place preferentially at step sites [37]. The second class of structure sensitivity refers to reactions that take place preferentially on two-dimensional (100) surfaces. What is peculiar about these reactions is that the introduction of steps in the (100) surface actually lowers the reactivity, quite contrary to the effect of steps in the (111) surface as discussed for the previous class of structure sensitivity. Reactions for which this effect has been documented include the ammonia oxidation on stepped Pt surfaces [38], the oxidation of dimethylether on stepped Pt surfaces [39], the reduction of oxygen on stepped Au surfaces in alkaline media [40], and the reduction of CO to ethylene on stepped Cu surfaces [41,42]. We will illustrate here the electrocatalytic reduction of nitrite on stepped platinum as a good example of this class, i.e., of a reaction taking place preferentially on two-dimensional (100) terraces [43]. Fig. 4 illustrates the reduction of the nitrite anion on a series on stepped platinum single-crystal electrodes in 0.1M NaOH electrolyte. In this case, the terrace has (100) orientation and the steps have either (111) orientation (Fig. 4A) or (110) orientation (Fig. 4B). Fig. 4 shows that there are two major reduction peaks associated with nitrite reduction: a large reduction peak centered at ca. 0.4V, corresponding to the complete reduction of nitrite to ammonia: (4) NO 2 - + 5 H 2 O + 6 e - → NH 3 + 7 OH - A second smaller peak is centered at around 0.58V and corresponds to the selective reduction of nitrite to dinitrogen, as confirmed by online electrochemical mass spectrometry: (5) NO 2 - + 2 H 2 O + 3 e - → 1 / 2 N 2 + 4 OH - Especially this latter reaction is rather unique and the Pt(100) facet is the only catalytic surface known to catalyze this reaction without the formation of the N2O intermediate [44]. Detailed experiments involving in situ FTIR spectroscopy and isotope labeling suggest that N2 is formed as the result of the coupling between a NH2 and a NO adsorbate on the (100) surface [43]. As Fig. 4A and B shows, both reactions are highly sensitive to the width of the (100) terrace. Steps in this case lower the overall reactivity. Fig. 4C plots the charge associated with the peak at 0.58V corresponding to reaction (5) and illustrates how quickly the N2 forming ability of the Pt surface declines as the two-dimensional character of the (100) facets is perturbed. A similar effect is observed for the ammonia-forming reduction peak, though this reaction still shows some reactivity on surfaces with a high step density. It is important to emphasize that for this class of reactions, catalytic activity is optimal on two-dimensional (100) terraces. Steps of (100) orientation have no, or a much lower, reactivity. Reactivity patterns very similar to those described in Fig. 4 for nitrite reduction on platinum have been observed for ammonia oxidation on platinum, oxygen reduction on gold, carbon monoxide reduction on copper, and dimethylether oxidation on platinum. For the latter reaction, we have recently performed density functional theory calculations showing that the critical bond breaking reaction takes place preferentially on an active site consisting of four surface atoms arranged in a square [45]. Since the density of such sites is high on a two-dimensional (100) surface or terrace, this would explain why (100) is such an active surface for the bond breaking reaction. The third class of structure sensitivity basically groups together all electrocatalytic reactions for which the structure sensitivity is not so clear or well-defined, or is strongly dependent on the electrolyte composition, in particular on the presence of anions that may compete with the reactant for adsorption sites on the surfaces [11]. A good example of the latter phenomenon is the reduction of nitrate on Pt single-crystal electrodes. While Pt(110) is the most active surface in perchloric acid, Pt(111) is the most active surface for nitrate reduction in sulfuric acid [46]. This has been attributed to the competition between nitrate and sulfate adsorption. Oxygen reduction, a very important reaction for the development of low-temperature Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells (PEMFCs), is another example for which the observed structure sensitivity using single-crystal electrodes is not straightforward to interpret [11]. Using an extensive series of single-crystal electrodes, the group of Feliu has studied the ORR on platinum in perchloric and sulfuric acid solution [47,48]. The ORR appears to be much more structure sensitive in sulfuric acid than in perchloric acid, though in both electrolytes Pt(221) and Pt(331) appear to be the most active surfaces [48]. In alkaline media, the Pt(111) surface appears to be the most active surface for the ORR of the three low-index planes [49], which appears to a rather common structure sensitivity trend for this class of reactions. 3.2 Electrocatalysis on well-defined shape-controlled nanoparticles Insight and knowledge gleaned from single-crystal model experiments should aid in the design of functional catalytic nanoparticles. With the impressive progress in the shape-controlled synthesis of nanoparticles, it is now possible to tailor-make particles with preferentially oriented facets [50,51]. Below, we will show that the two classes of structure sensitivity discussed in the previous section lead to the different requirements for optimal “nano-catalysis”. Since the oxidation of carbon monoxide requires steps in the (111) facet, Lee et al. [52] have prepared Pt nanoparticles with a varying amount of high-index planes by subjecting Pt nanoparticles to different heat treatments and subsequent inspection of the nanoparticles by high-resolution TEM to estimate the fraction of high-index planes (see Fig. 5 ). The stripping of pre-adsorbed carbon monoxide on such particles was studied by both stripping voltammetry and chronoamperometry (Fig. 5A and B). The experiments clearly showed that high-index planes with a large number of step sites enhance the oxidation of adsorbed carbon monoxide (Fig. 5F), in agreement with the results of the single-crystal model experiments. Annealing of the nanoparticles by cycling them in a solution saturated with carbon monoxide is known to lead to a lowering of the number of step sites on the particles, and as a result, the reactivity toward CO stripping lowers (see Fig. 5F). The practical consequence of these results is that reactions that require step sites for a high catalytic activity profit from a high fraction of high-index planes. Since such planes can only develop on sufficiently large particles, catalytically active nanoparticles should not be too small. Indeed, Arenz et al. [53] have shown that smaller Pt nanoparticles are less active for CO stripping and ascribed this size dependence to the lack of steps and defects in the facets of small particles. Tian et al. [54] have developed an electrochemical procedure for generating nanoparticles with high-index facets. The method involves the extensive potential cycling of Pt nanoparticles, which is supposed to generate high-index facets during the oxidative parts of the cycle. In agreement with single-crystal model studies, which showed that high-index facets have a high activity for the oxidation of alcohols such as ethanol [36], they showed that these nanoparticles exhibit a high activity for the electrocatalytic oxidation of ethanol [54,55]. Electrocatalytic reactions that show their highest activity on (100) single-crystal surfaces require nanoparticles with a large fraction of (100) facets. Ideally, such nanoparticles have a cubic or cuboid shape. Vidal-Iglesias et al. were the first to show that cubic platinum nanoparticles are superior nano-catalysts for the oxidation of ammonia in alkaline solution [56]. Their nanoparticles were prepared by a colloidal method. Fig. 6 shows the reduction of nitrite on (100) preferentially oriented platinum nanoparticles in comparison with the single-crystal surfaces [57]. The nanoparticles in Fig. 6 were prepared by cathodic corrosion, a novel method for nanoparticle preparation that may under certain conditions yield nanoparticles with a high fraction of (100) facets [58,59]. Fig. 6C–E shows that these particles also exhibit the selective reduction of nitrite to N2, as evidenced by the mass spectrometry traces. The particles in Fig. 6 have a diameter of ca. 12nm. Colloidal cubic nanoparticles such as those prepared by Vidal-Iglesias et al. [56] have a typical size of 9–10nm. The preparation of smaller nanoparticles (say <6nm) with a large fraction of (100) facets is still a challenge. Another aspect of electrocatalysis on nanoparticles that needs to be discussed briefly here is the so-called particle size effect. This effect is especially relevant for the activity of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), since the economical use of platinum is critical for the application of this reaction in PEMFCs. The particle size effect for the ORR on Pt is strongly debated in the literature [11,60]. The most typical observation is the activity of Pt nanoparticles for the ORR decreases with nanoparticle size, leading to a maximum in mass activity as a function of particle size, though other groups have reported that particle size has no influence on the specific ORR activity. Nesselberger et al. [61] have recently confirmed the strong sensitivity of the rate of the ORR on nanoparticulate Pt catalysts to the nature of the electrolyte anion and pointed out that the single-crystal measurements cannot explain the particle size dependence that is observed for particles larger than 10nm. Perez-Alonso et al. [62] have studied the particle size dependence of the ORR for a range of mass-selected Pt nanoparticles deposited onto a flat support, allowing for a high level of control over the particle size distribution. The specific ORR activity was found to decrease with particle size, and the mass activity was found to peak at a particle size of ca. 3nm, in agreement with earlier studies [60]. Perez-Alonso et al. concluded that the active sites for the ORR on Pt nanoparticles are mainly located on the terraces on the nanoparticles. 4 Electronic effects in electrocatalysis 4.1 Electrocatalytic properties and surface composition In practice, after the analysis of the impact of structural aspects, it is often necessary to optimize and improve the performance of catalytic sites at the surface. By changing the electronic structure of the surface, it is possible to influence its activity, selectivity, and stability. According to the well-known Sabatier principle [63], the surface of an active electrocatalyst should be able to activate the reactants and at the same time should not bind the reaction intermediates too strongly to prevent poisoning of active sites. The quantitative parameters (“descriptors”) which largely determine the catalyst activity are the binding (adsorption) energies of the reaction intermediates for different catalytic sites located at the surface [64–66]. Essentially, these binding energies depend on the electronic structure of the surface. For a given (metal) facet or for a selected type of surface sites, one of the classical ways of optimizing their electronic structure is to alter the bulk composition or the composition of the topmost and/or sub-surface atomic layers by a second metal. It should be noted here that changing the composition may also help in providing the necessary stability of the catalysts under real reaction conditions and additionally provides flexibility to regulate their selectivity. Perhaps the most difficult task in tailoring electrocatalytic properties by altering the electronic structure of specific sites at the surface is to be able to predict how changes in the composition would influence the resultant activity, stability, and selectivity. Rational design of electrocatalysts assumes that the properties are tailored purposefully, when the nature and the exact position of the dopant species at the surface are selected based on fundamental understanding of how this would change the performance of the active sites, and how this would influence the catalyst stability and selectivity. Another key requirement is to be able to implement efficient synthetic routes and schemes to obtain the desired surfaces. Recent progress in the theory of heterogeneous electrocatalysis supported by new unique opportunities in the field of computational quantum chemistry enabled better understanding of the electronic effects and made computational design of novel active materials possible [67–70]. New theoretical concepts allow explaining and, most importantly, predicting catalytic properties of surfaces with different composition and structure [71–75]. On the other hand, knowledge accumulated in the field of surface science is nowadays successfully used to control surface composition precisely, while implementing the synthetic routes under conditions which can be easily adapted to use them in industrial applications. In the following, we will focus mainly on bi-metallic systems and discuss fundamental aspects of how changes in composition result in optimization of the electronic structure of the surface and hence improve its electrocatalyst performance. Two processes, the electrochemical reduction of the molecular oxygen and nitrate-ions ( NO 3 - ) , will be considered as the model reactions. 4.2 Activity and stability descriptors As it was mentioned above, the electrocatalyst performance at a given electrode potential is to a large extent determined by the status and properties of the electrode surface. If the activity has to be improved, the capability to calculate the binding energies of reaction intermediates using quantum chemistry approaches, particularly using density functional theory calculations (DFT), has drastically facilitated identification of new electrocatalysts for many important reactions. Practically, this identification is based on a concept of “descriptors” [76–82]. While electrocatalytic materials working under real conditions represent complex multiparametric systems, it is often possible to find only one or few parameters (“descriptors”) which mainly control their performance. For the overall electrocatalytic activity, the Sabatier principle suggests the descriptors to be experimentally measured or, alternatively, ab initio calculated binding energies of the intermediates at different sites of the surface. In many cases, selection of the particular activity descriptors is facilitated owing to the observation that for reactions involving several different intermediates, their binding energies tend to scale linearly with each other [82–84]. Therefore, to describe the activity trends, it suffices to use calculated binding energies for just one type of intermediate. One of the best examples is the electrochemical oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) taking place at the surface of metal electrodes. It is now well-accepted that the ORR involves at least three intermediates adsorbed at the surface: *OOH, *O, and *OH, where (*) denotes the adsorbed species. However, Fig. 7 demonstrates that the overall ORR activity of Pt alloys can be fairly described using only one descriptor, namely the oxygen binding energy. All the experimental points presented in Fig. 7 for the platinum alloy surfaces form a Sabatier-type volcano-shaped plot. According to this descriptor-based model, the optimal catalyst for the ORR should bind the *O species approximately 0.2eV weaker than a pure Pt surface (Fig. 7), i.e., the optimal surface should be slightly “more noble” compared to Pt. This descriptor (*O-binding energy) is relatively easy to estimate using DFT calculations, allowing for computational screening of a large number of catalyst candidates to determine the materials that have the optimal reactivity. This approach has recently resulted in the discovery of new catalyst materials, particularly for the oxygen reduction reaction, as will be discussed later. Another key property of electrocatalysts is their long-term stability under real conditions of electrochemical systems. For instance, oxygen reduction reaction at the cathode side of working polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) takes place at high potentials in acidic media. Even state-of-the-art Pt-based electrocatalysts can degrade relatively fast under these circumstances [86]. Therefore, the ability to optimize the composition in order to improve the stability is often as important as to increase the electrocatalytic activity. However, only few descriptors were proposed in the literature to address the stability issue. One of these descriptors is the free energy of formation for the corresponding compounds, particularly for bulk-, surface-, and sub-surface alloys [85,87]. Notably, it turned out that stability issues could be, at least partially, addressed by tailoring the electronic structure of the surface. The latter does not only change the binding energies for the reaction intermediates but also influences the ability of the surface to bind species which are responsible for the catalyst degradation. For example, it is now understood that anodic degradation of Pt catalysts in PEMFCs cathodes starts with adsorption and subsequent incorporation of oxygenated species into the Pt lattice [88,89]. Therefore, making platinum surface slightly “more noble” with respect to the adsorption of *OOH, *OH, and *O species does not only increase its catalytic activity toward the ORR but can also improve the stability of the catalyst itself. However, there are no universal descriptors which would link the stability of the surface under real (or comparable) electrochemical conditions with its electronic structure. Each particular case requires a time-consuming detailed analysis using DFT calculations with subsequent experimental evaluation of the material [90]. This situation calls for the development of new more universal and robust stability descriptors to facilitate rational design of optimal electrocatalysts. We note that similar challenges also exist in addressing selectivity of electrocatalysts. Selectivity is connected to favoring one or a few desired reaction pathways among competing pathways. A full system analysis is required in this case [91], which is normally very time and resource consuming. Summarizing, recent progress in understanding the electronic effects at the surface largely facilitated identification and design of active electrocatalysts. Addressing of stability and selectivity issues will be important challenges for the future. 4.3 Tailoring the surface electronic properties using bi-metallic bulk alloys Practically, for a given electrocatalytic surface with a defined structure, the binding of the electroactive species and, consequently, the overall activity can be adjusted by utilizing two different effects: ligand effects and strain effects. One speaks of ligand effects when the atoms at the active sites are influenced by neighboring atoms with a dissimilar atomic number, causing a change in their electronic structure [92]. Strain effects occur when the catalyst is strained parallel to its surface as the lattice parameter of the surface will tend toward that of the bulk material. This can cause either a compressive lattice strain which can weaken the binding of the surface atoms to the electroactive species or a tensile strain which has the opposite effect. A classical way to benefit from both effects in case of metallic systems is to prepare bulk alloys, especially when the topmost atomic layer consists of just a pure host metal. In many cases, one can benefit from a predominantly ligand effect if only sub-monolayer amounts of solute metals are used at the surface or in the sub-surface region forming surface and sub-surface alloys. One example of the rational design of electrocatalysts using bulk bimetallic alloys deals with identification of new active and stable catalysts for the ORR in PEMFCs. A high-throughput screening which was performed by Greeley et al. [85] involved the search of Pt3X(111) and Pd3X(111) model alloy surfaces (X denotes a solute metal) where the topmost layers consisted of either pure Pt or Pd. The particular selection of these systems for the screening procedure has been dictated by the fact that the author’s theoretical analysis identified the most active sites for the ORR at Pt- and Pd-based catalytic surfaces to be the (111) facets. Therefore, these structural aspects and restrictions in the material choice (Pt and Pd are among only few materials which can be utilized under the extreme conditions of PEMFCs cathodes) resulted in the attempt to optimize the electronic structure of this particular facet. Using the oxygen binding energy as the activity descriptor and the alloying energy as the stability descriptor, two binary bulk alloys, Pt3Y and Pt3Sc, were identified [85]. Experimental evaluation of the activity of these alloys indeed confirmed their high activity and good stability. Remarkably, Pt3Y appeared to be one of the most active catalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction known up to date (see Fig. 7). Nevertheless, according to the descriptor-based model (Fig. 7), Pt3Y is still not located at the exact optimum for this reaction: its surface binds *O-intermediates slightly stronger than required. Therefore, to further optimize the activity of the Pt–Y system, attempts were undertaken to adjust the bulk concentration of Y to reach the optimum activity. Several intermetallic Pt x Y compounds: Pt5Y, Pt3Y, Pt2Y, and PtY were tested [93]. While the initial increase in the concentration of Y increases the activity in the following order Pt<Pt5Y<Pt3Y, introduction of more yttrium resulted in unexpected problems with the stability of the corresponding bulk alloys. Pt2Y demonstrated both reduced activity and stability, while PtY appeared to be not chemically stable in aqueous media. This underlines the complexity of multiparametric optimization of electrocatalytic systems even in the case of relatively simple bi-metallic systems, as the stability, activity and, in many cases, selectivity have to be taken into account simultaneously. In bi-metallic alloys, the ability to tailor the catalytic properties by changing the bulk composition generally depends on the existence of intermetallic phases. Otherwise, long-term stability issues under real conditions of the electrochemical environment would likely become dominant. The example with the Pt–Y systems demonstrates that there is a deficiency of “degrees of freedom” to tailor the bulk content of the solute element quasi-continuously. This can be partially compensated by changing the nature of the solute metal. Considering further the alloys of platinum with (early) transition metals with respect to electrocatalysis of oxygen reduction, further attempts to optimize the ORR activity were made by alloying Pt with transition metals located close to Y in the periodic system, such as La, Hf, and Gd. Fig. 8 summarizes the oxygen reduction activities for some platinum alloys which have been discovered as a result of these attempts. At least two (new) tested alloys, namely Pt5La [94] and Pt5Gd [95], have demonstrated high ORR activity. However, none of them appeared to be at the exact optimum in terms of oxygen binding energy. The composition of the sub-surface regions in these alloys (as well as the Pt–Y alloys) after exposing them to the real conditions of the oxygen reduction reaction revealed that the catalytic surface was formed by several compressed atomic layers of pure platinum, as schematically shown in Fig. 8. Therefore, the origin of the enhanced ORR activity of Pt5La and Pt5Gd is predominantly the compressive strain effect. In summary, recent theoretical advances in combination with an experimental strategy for the optimization of the electronic structure of the surface (using bulk alloying) resulted in the discovery of several completely new active ORR catalysts. In the following, alternative strategies which involve optimization of the electronic structure by sub-monolayer and monolayer amounts of metals located at the surface will be discussed. 4.4 Optimization of electrocatalysts using adatoms, surface, and sub-surface alloys Fig. 9 A shows schematically a possible variety of active sites with dissimilar binding energies and which can be formed at the surface of metallic electrodes, if the composition and the exact position of the solute atoms are precisely controlled. The figure illustrates the many of new degrees of freedom to tailor the electronic properties of active sites as compared to those discussed in the previous sub-section. Fig. 9B also shows some possible synthetic routs (involving electrochemical steps) which can be used to control the position of foreign atoms at the surface. These routes are based on several phenomena known and exhaustively studied in the fields of electrochemical surface science and ultra-high vacuum (UHV) surface science. One of these phenomena is so-called electrochemical underpotential deposition (UPD) of monolayer amounts of foreign atoms at electrode potentials more positive to those necessary to form the bulk (3D) phase of the same material [97]. This phenomenon originates from the fact that the first layer of a foreign metal can in some cases bind to the electrode surface with a greater binding energy compared to the normal bonding in the metal lattice. Therefore, UPD is a surface limited process where the surface coverage of (metal) adatoms can be precisely controlled by varying the electrode potential. Recently, various UPD-assisted synthetic schemes have gained popularity, as it is a robust and cheap method to tailor the surface structure and composition very accurately [98–109]. On the other hand, capitalizing upon the knowledge obtained from UHV surface science, the position of the electrochemically deposited atomic layers can be controlled using annealing in specific atmospheres (Fig. 9B). For example, electrochemically deposited sub-monolayer and monolayer amounts of Cu atoms can be selectively moved between the first and the second platinum layers either by annealing the electrode at 400°C in Ar/CO (0.1%) or Ar/H2 (5%) atmospheres [104]. The exact atmosphere and temperatures were elucidated in separate model UHV-experiments [110]. Furthermore, the stability of Cu in the sub-surface layer of Pt has been confirmed by DFT calculations, supporting the experimental findings [110]. Additionally, computational methods, particularly DFT calculations, can elucidate the adsorption energy distribution in all possible cases created by the introduction of foreign atoms to the sub-surface region or at the surface. Therefore, this theoretical insight together with new synthetic routes enables efficient tailoring of the important surface properties. Fig. 10 provides one example where the electronic properties of a platinum monolayer are tailored by depositing it onto different host metals, such as Au(111), Pd(111), Rh(111), Ir(111), and Ru(0001) [98], with the aim to catalyze the oxygen reduction reaction. The nature of the substrate determines the properties of the platinum monolayer and influences the binding energies with which the surface binds oxygenated species, for instance *O. Consequently, this changes the activity of the platinum monolayer toward the oxygen reduction reaction. Being plotted as a function of the calculated oxygen binding energy, the series of PtML/substrate systems forms a typical volcano-shaped plot (Fig. 10) with PtML/Pd(111) having the highest activity among them. Therefore, by depositing the same platinum monolayer on different substrate, one can efficiently tailor its electrocatalytic properties. An alternative approach to optimize the electronic and, thus, adsorption properties of a surface is to vary the concentration of a solute element in the sub-surface region. For example, incorporation of Cu atoms into the second atomic layer of platinum leads to a surface that binds oxygenated species weaker than pure Pt(111) [107]. Moreover, the binding energies depend on sub-surface concentration of the solute element. This is illustrated in Fig. 11 A, where theoretical and experimental shifts in the *OH-binding energy are plotted as a function of the amount of initially deposited (using UPD) Cu atoms. It should be noted that some deviation between the theoretical and experimentally measured binding energies at higher Cu coverages in Fig. 11A is due to a deviation between expected and experimentally obtained sub-surface concentrations of copper [107]. As sub-surface copper changes the adsorption energies of oxygenated species quasi-continuously depending on its sub-surface concentration, this approach has been used to tailor the activity of Pt electrodes toward the oxygen reduction. Fig. 11B shows how the experimental ORR activity of Cu–Pt(111) sub-surface alloys changes with the amount of atoms of the solute metal. In these alloys, Cu is preferentially located in the second atomic layer of the host platinum single-crystal electrodes. Up to 8-fold improvement in the oxygen reduction reaction, activity over the pure Pt(111) surface can be reached when just approximately ½ ML of copper is introduced into the second layer of the host metal. This is due to the fact that at this composition, the value of the descriptor (in this case the OH binding energy, Fig. 11C) is close to the optimum. Notably, the activity of the Cu–Pt(111) sub-surface alloys approaches that known for the best ORR electrocatalyst ever reported, Pt3Ni(111) (compare Figs. 7 and 11C); and the origin of this improved activity is predominantly the ligand effect. Somewhat counterintuitively, the resultant Cu–Pt(111) sub-surface alloys demonstrated stable ORR activity under conditions relevant for PEMFCs for at least several hours, without notable surface segregation effects. However, stability issues should be further investigated in detail to confirm the earlier DFT analysis performed for this sub-surface alloy [110]. It should be noted that the Cu–Pt(111) sub-surface alloys represent not only a theoretical interest. It has been recently demonstrated that extended thin films of Cu–Pt(111) sub-surface alloys with a high ORR activity can be successfully prepared [99,111,112], showing promise that model single-crystalline electrocatalysts can also be up-scaled for applications. By varying the nature of both substrates and overlayers, it is possible to change not only the activity, but also selectivity in many electrocatalytic systems. One of these examples deals with electrochemical reduction of nitrate-ions in aqueous media (Fig. 12 ). Depending on the nature of the overlayers on Pt substrates, it is possible to change the resultant product from preferentially NO (on Cuad/Pt [113]) to N2O (on Snad/Pt [114]), or from NH2OH to NH 4 + (if Ge monolayer on Pd [115] is changed to Sn or Cu, Fig. 12). However, in these cases, selectivity is also highly dependent on the electrolyte composition. If selectivity of a particular system is established, the activity can be further optimized by performing a full analysis of possible coverages and relative positions of solute atoms at the surface. DFT calculations can be efficiently used in these optimizations to rank relevant adsorption energies at different sites. One example of such analysis is the optimization of an Ag–Au system (Fig. 12). It has been elucidated that modification of Au with sub-monolayer amounts of Ag at the surface leads to a catalyst which is selective toward the electrochemical reduction of nitrate to nitrite in acidic perchloric media according to the following reaction [116]: NO 3 - + 2 H + + 2 e - → NO 2 - + H 2 O The limiting stage in this reduction reaction is believed to be the adsorption of NO 3 - [117]. Therefore, the increase in binding energy for some specific active sites in the Ag–Au system would likely lead to the improvement of the overall activity toward the nitrate reduction. Fig. 13 summarizes the results of the full DFT analysis of the Ag–Au system performed by Calle-Vallejo et al. [118]. It was generally observed that the nitrate adsorption is facilitated at the surface with a high abundance of surface atoms with a lower coordination number (Fig. 13A). Sub-surface Ag does not change the nitrate binding energy at the (111) facets (Fig. 13B) nor at the (100) facets and stepped surfaces. In contrast, Ag–Au surface alloys increase the nitrate binding energy significantly. Ag adatoms bind NO 3 - even stronger, however, a complete Ag monolayer on either Au(111), Au(100) or stepped Au surfaces bind the nitrate weaker than Ag adatoms on the corresponding surfaces, as schematically shown in Fig. 13B. Finally, pure Ag binds NO 3 - weaker than the corresponding Ag overlayers. Therefore, this DFT analysis suggests that to optimize the activity of the Ag–Au system, it is necessary to create an abundance of surface Ag adatoms with a lower coordination number (i.e., sub-monolayer amounts of Ag adatoms should give the maximum activity). The Au surface should ideally be also fairly defective (Fig. 13A). Fig. 13C shows the results of the experimental activity evaluation verifying this hypothesis. The maximum of the experimental activity is reached at the coverage of approximately 2/3ML. Moreover, the resultant catalyst showed excellent stability with time under the reaction conditions. Thus, the detailed DFT analysis coupled with simple experimental optimization resulted in a creation of the selective, active, and stable Ag–Au electrocatalyst. 4.5 Implementation of real-world nanoparticulate electrocatalysts The knowledge obtained from model experiments can be successfully used to design “real-world electrocatalysts”. For example, one of the main modern paradigms of the PEMFCs electrocatalyst preparation is to produce high surface area nanoparticulate materials where the catalyst nanoparticles are supported on an electronically conducting carbon support [119]. As stability issues strongly dominate in selection of electrocatalyst material, Pt-based materials are used at the cathode side of present state-of-the-art PEMFCs [120–124]. The performance of Pt nanoparticles can be improved by utilizing the same ideas and approaches which were discussed in previous sections for the case of model single crystals or some other extended surfaces. One of the recent illustrative examples capitalizes upon the knowledge obtained from model experiments to prepare highly active PtNi nanoparticles with maximum abundance of the (111) facets [125]. Consequently, structural and electronic effects are taken into account simultaneously. Fig. 14 summarizes the results of microscopic and electrochemical characterization of octahedral PtNi nanoparticles with very similar sizes (from ∼9nm to ∼9.5nm), but different composition (from 31at.% to 40at.% of Pt, correspondingly). The octahedral shape of the nanoparticles (Fig. 14A–C) enables creation of the highest possible abundance of the most active (111) facets, while the growth rate under specific surfactant-free conditions allows further tuning of the composition and, hence, of the electronic structure and activity of these facets. Up to 10-fold improvement in activity over the state-of-the-art commercial ORR electrocatalysts was obtained for the ∼9.5nm nanoparticles with approximately 40at.% of Pt in the near-surface region (Fig. 14D). Considering that it has been estimated that for a wider commercialization of PEMFCs, the ORR activity of the state-of-the-art commercial Pt electrocatalysts should be increased by 4–10 times [126–128], this is a remarkable example of how fundamental knowledge and careful analysis of structural and electronic effects can lead to a breakthrough development of the highly important electrocatalysts. However, it should be noted here that while direct transfer of the knowledge obtained as a result of experiments with model well-defined systems normally results in substantial improvement of electrocatalysts, nanoparticle materials are much more complex systems compared to single crystals (see Fig. 1). The performance of the real world electrocatalysts is largely influenced also by surface morphology, for instance nanoporosity, catalyst–support interactions, and composition of deeper sub-surface layers (beyond the second layer) [129–132]. These effects should be taken into consideration to design efficient catalysts. On the other hand, stability issues with respect to the nanoparticulate cathode PEMFCs electrocatalysts have recently led to a growing interest to replace nanoparticles with high surface area thin films [99,111,133–136]. The destabilizing effect of the excessive surface energy in case of nanoparticles could be avoided by a proper design of thin Pt(Pd)-based films active toward the ORR. Capitalizing upon the activity and stability data reported by Greeley et al. for the newly identified Pt3Y catalyst, Yoo et al. [137] synthesized active and stable thin Pt3Y films. A 16-fold improvement in the activity over a corresponding reference Pt thin film was obtained. Importantly, the activity remained almost unchanged after the accelerated stability test involving 3000 cycles. 5 Conclusions Structural and electronic effects play a key role in rational design of electrocatalysts. Recent progress in understanding these effects has resulted in the discovery and development of many new catalysts with improved performance. In this paper, we have illustrated how the structure of single-crystal surfaces influences electrocatalytic reactions, and how a possible categorization of this structure sensitivity leads to structural requirements for the corresponding nanoparticulate electrocatalysts. Electronic effects of electrocatalysts were illustrated to be tuned by alloying, surface alloying, and sub-surface alloying, allowing for subtle changes in the catalyst properties. Such subtle changes have resulted in improved catalyst surfaces, both single crystalline and nanoparticulate. These surface-science approaches, based on atomic-level surface control and theoretical–computational understanding of key steps and bottlenecks in the catalytic reaction mechanisms, pave the way for a rational approach toward electrocatalyst design, and it can be envisaged that further progress in this field will provide unique opportunities in designing of new generations of efficient, stable, and selective electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: Recent advances in the understanding of structural and electronic effects in heterogeneous electrocatalysis are summarized. Typical examples are given illustrating how the knowledge obtained from a detailed theoretical analysis of structural and electronic effects supported by model experiments can be used for the rational design of new electrocatalytic materials. Recent successes and future challenges in designing active, stable, and selective electrocatalysts are discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Structural and electronic effects in heterogeneous electrocatalysis: Toward a rational design of electrocatalysts
